Analyze the user review below and identify mentions of product attributes.


**Product Unstructured Information:**
**Product Title:** Crop-A-Dile 2 Big Bite Punch by We R Memory Keepers | Silver and Blue

**Product Price:** $38.12

**Product Description:** ['The Crop-A-Dile 2 Big Bite Punch by We R Memory Keepers is an all-in-one tool for punching, setting, and embellishing every crafting project. Use eyelets, grommets and more to add the right amount of bling to cards, scrapbook layouts, book covers, and many other home dcor or crafting concept. Easily reaches to the center of a 12 x 12-inch page. Highly adjustable measurement settings, removable feet, and rotating setting cube make the Big Bite stand out from other crafting punches.']

**Product Features:**
- Metal','rubber
- Imported
- INCREDIBLE REACH: What sets this tool apart from the rest is its six-inch reach, that allows you to easily extend to the center of a 12 x 12 page.
- ALL-IN-ONE TOOL: Punches clean holes at 1/8 and 3/16 of an inch. Setting apparatus allows you to easily lock an embellishment into place. Adjustable measuring guide helps get the perfect measurement every time. Rotating setting cube wont have you fumbling around for loose pieces.
- EMBELLISH ANY PROJECT: The Crop-A-Dile Big Bite allows you to add eyelets, grommets and other embellishments to any crafting project.
- VERSATILE: Designed to be a desktop tool, but light enough to be lifted up to get to those hard-to-reach areas.
- STRONG: Can easily punch through a variety of materials including paper, leather, fabric, plastic, thin tin, chipboard, and so much more.


**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**
- Brand: We R Memory Keepers
- Main Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Scrapbooking & Stamping
- Price Range: $25-$50

**User Review Content:**
Title: Better than other eyelet setting tools I've tried, but... Review: Before I bought this product, I tried setting eyelets with a HomePro 2 Hand Eyelet Tool. However the eyelet setter kept sliding back into its base, which made the tool unusable. I next tried a hammer and punch, after first punching a hole in the card stock. This technique worked, although the eyelets tended to deform into peculiar shapes, and I whacked my thumb with the hammer a couple of times. The Crop-A-Dile II Big Bite Punch (CAD II BBP)is my third attempt to set eyelets, and it performs better than the first two methods. However, the CAD II BBP is by no means perfect. The top and bottom cubes that rotate so you can punch the correct size of eyelet have a bit of wiggle room, so that the top and bottom points don't come precisely together. The tool can still set eyelets, but one side of the eyelet gets a bit more squashed down than the other side. My favorite feature, and the reason I bought the CAD II BBP is its long reach. If I choose to, I can set eyelets in the middle of my greeting cards instead of having to limit myself to the edges of the cards. The HomePro 2 Hand Eyelet Tool (while it was still working) could only set eyelets at the edges of cards.

**Task:**

2.  **Determine Sentiment:** Is the user's attitude towards this entity Positive, Neutral, or Negative?
3.  **Apply Filtering Rules (CRITICAL):**
    *   **Logic A: Negative Entities (COMPLAINTS):**
        *   **Action:** **ALWAYS KEEP**.
        *   **Reasoning:** If a user complains about something (Negative), it is a valid preference regardless of whether the product claims to have it.
        *   **Requirement:** You MUST provide an `improvement_wish`.
            *   *Explicit:* Use what they asked for (e.g., "wanted it smaller").
            *   *Implicit:* Infer the opposite (e.g., "too fragile" -> Wish: "Sturdy/Durable").
    *   **Logic B: Positive/Neutral Entities (VALIDATION):**
        *   **Action:** **CHECK SEMANTIC SIMILARITY**.
        *   **Test:** Does this entity semantically match ANY information in the **Known Product Attributes** OR **Product Unstructured Information** (Title/Description/Features)?
            *   *Yes (Match Found):* **KEEP IT**. This confirms the user noticed a real product feature.
            *   *No (No Match):* **DISCARD**. The user might be hallucinating or talking about something irrelevant to this specific product's data keys.

With design styles that are cute and adorable fun and whimsical and classically elegant these universal wafer-thin dies make a great addition to your paper crafting supplies. Cut amazing shapes out of paper cardstock adhesive-backed paper vinyl vellum and more. They are made from American steel and will work with the QuicKutz Revolution CuttleBug SpellBinder Wizard AccuCut Zip'eMate and Sizzix BigShot and BigKick machines (all sold separately). The die is a solid steel plate with multiple cutting images and comes with a layer of ejection foam to give clean and accurate cuts. This package contains Holiday Cardinal. Made in USA."] **Product Features:** - With design styles that are cute and adorable fun - Cut amazing shapes out of paper cardstock adhesive-backed paper vinyl vellum and more - Easy to use - International products have separate terms, are sold from abroad and may differ from local products, including fit, age ratings, and language of product, labeling or instructions. - Manufacturer warranty may not apply - Learn more about Amazon Global Store. **Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):** - Brand: CottageCutz - Main Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing - Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Die-Cuts, Die-Cutting & Embossing, Scrapbooking & Stamping - Price Range: $25-$50 **User Review Content:** Title: Die didn't cut cardstock very cleanly Review: Cottage Cutz sells an amazing variety of decorative dies. This particular example, the Holiday Cardinal yields twelve pieces of paper: the oval ivy border itself, which measures about four inches in length and three inches in width; there are also five sets of berries; the cardinal's body plus separate pieces for its black mask, yellow beak and feet, and black eye. Text-weight (60 lb) paper seems to yield the cleanest cut. When I attempted to cut regular cardstock (80 lb) with this die, I had to finish the cut with my trusty #11 X-Acto blade. All of the Cottage Cutz dies come with a thin piece of sticky-backed foam that you fit over the die face. That's all the preparation that is necessary to use their dies. I attempted to cut this die with both my Big Shot die cutting machine and my Sizzix Grand Calibur machine, but neither yielded a completely clean cut, even when I used a shim. It took an extra fifteen minutes to free up the oval ivy border from the excess card stock. Title: This angel makes a lovely Christmas card Review: Jolee's stickers are almost always best-in-class for decorating greeting cards. I like to use this angel with her accompanying snowflakes on Christmas cards. The angel sticker is built in layers, with her hands, horn, and fur trim comprising the top layer (see customer image for an example of a Christmas card decorated with this angel). Each snowflake sticker is embellished by a tiny crystal rhinestone. You simply peel the stickers off of the clear plastic sheet inside the package, and stick them to your card or scrapbook page. NOTE: the blue coloring shown in the product photograph is much deeper than the blue on the actual stickers.

**Product Unstructured Information:**
**Product Title:** Glue Dots Vellum Adhesive Sheets 10/Pkg, 3-Inch by 4-Inch

**Product Description:** ['GLUE DOTS-Vellum Adhesive Sheets. These repositionable double-sided adhesive sheets are transparent; even on dark surfaces and acid free. Use for bonding vellum; transparencies; skeleton leaves; glass and acrylic embellishments and much more. This package contains ten 4 by 3-inch sheets. Contents conform to ASTM D4236. Made in USA.']

**Product Features:**
- Acid-free VellumGlue Dotsare truly transparent double-sided adhesive dots for vellum papers, trans


**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**
- Brand: Glue Dots
- Main Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Scrapbooking & Stamping

**User Review Content:**
Title: This product doesn't perform as advertised Review: I should have been wary of a product that advertises itself both as "repositionable" and "bonds instantly." These adhesive sheets are indeed repositionable. You can reposition them all day. My problem is that they didn't bond the interior vellum sheet of my wedding card to the exterior paper. I tried three separate sheets out of a package of ten, and all they did was make the paper, the vellum, and ultimately my hands slightly sticky. Possibly the adhesive sheets didn't work because I had the sealed package in my possession for a couple of years before I tried them out, and the glue somehow evaporated. Needless to say, the sheets went into the wastebasket, and I resorted to Plan B which was tying the vellum interior to the exterior card with a ribbon. I won't buy this particular Glue Dots product again, even though I regularly use their other products.

**User Review Content:**
Title: The little curly bits don't always cut Review: I'd been looking high and low for a 'Happy Birthday' die and this one from Sizzix is quite lovely. However, when used with a Cuttlebug machine, it doesn't completely cut out the letters, especially the curly bits, and I have to go after them with a craft knife. It sometimes takes half an hour to free the letters from the surrounding paper, which isn't what I would call a time-saver. However, the results are very pretty. See customer image above for one of the greeting cards I made from this die, plus a die from the Spellbinders S5-051 Mega Dies Fanciful Flight package. Here is the layering technique that, after much experimentation, I learned gives the best results with this Sizzix die in the Cuttlebug machine (from the bottom up): A Plate Cuttlebug manual (for padding) B Plate Happy Birthday die with cutting edge face-up paper with decorative side face-down B Plate

**User Review Content:**
Title: I had several problems with these markers Review: I was disappointed because the ink didn't flow smoothly from the tips of these broad point markers, except for the silver marker which worked just fine. Silver was also the only ink to show a true metallic sheen. These pens are still usable, if I retrace my lines until the color is uniform, but a better set of metallic markers is manufactured by Prang: Prang Metallic Washable Marker. You also get an extra color (green) from Prang, and the Prang set is cheaper. Both sets of markers are advertised as acid-free (archival quality) but the Prang markers flow more freely and create a broader line. Both sets of pens can be used on dark or light paper. Prang markers dry within seconds on glossy paper. e.g.photographs. The American Crafts pens smudged on glossy paper after being allowed to dry for a minute. Maybe I got a bad set of American Crafts metallic markers, but I'm definitely a convert to the Prang brand.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Nice for layering on A2 greeting cards Review: I didn't have any problems with a bad smell, as did the other reviewer of this product, and the 60 4.5"x6.5" papers are very nice for layering on A2 (4.25"x5.5") greeting cards (see above customer image for an example of a card using one of the flowery sheets from this stack). There are 18 different patterns (3 or 4 sheets for each pattern) each with discretely applied glitter that doesn't rub off. Most of the patterns are abstract stripes, dots, and rectangles, with the occasional flower pattern, and a couple of argyle shapes. The sheets are mostly done in pastel colors, except for the five sets at the bottom of the pack which are mainly colored silver and gray, with some black and white detail--these are really handy for masculine-themed cards. The paper is advertised as acid free, and is a nice weight for layering

**Product Title:** Spellbinders S5-051 Mega Dies Fanciful Flight

**Product Description:** ["Donna Salazar's Fanciful Flight die template set holds special meaning for her. The large butterfly features a lacey design to cut/emboss and use with a stamp overlay designed by Donna as well. The complete set includes a Bee, Dragonfly and a smaller solid Butterfly to metamorphasize your cards, scrapbooks and mixed media art. **Product Features:**
- Set includes a bee, dragonfly and a smaller solid butterfly
- Set of 4
- Approximate die template sizes: bee: 1-inch by 15/8-inch, small butterfly: 17/8-inch by 11/4-inch, dragonfly: 21/8-inch by 35/8-inch, large butterfly: 31/4-inch by 35/8-inch


**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**
- Brand: Spellbinders
- Main Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Die-Cuts, Die-Cutting & Embossing, Scrapbooking & Stamping

**User Review Content:**
Title: These shapes could be used for a range of greeting cards Review: I'm a big fan of the Spellbinders Shapeabilities dies, and this particular set of 2 butterfly dies, a dragonfly die, and a bee die makes it easy to create a range of nice-looking greeting cards. Just cut, emboss, and add glitter (EK Success Martha Stewart Crafts Iridescent Glitter Glue, 12-Pack is one of my essential decorating tools). See customer image above for a birthday card that I made with the large butterfly die. The smaller butterfly die was used to decorate the interior of this birthday card. I use my Spellbinders Shapeabilities dies with a Cuttlebug machine. The directions on how to use these dies with the Spellbinders Wizard, the Big Kick by Sizzix, and the Cuttlebug by Provocraft come with every set of dies, and they are very clear and easy to follow. If you are going to emboss using a Cuttlebug and the Shapeabilities Spellbinders dies, you will also need to purchase Spellbinders W-005 12 by 12 Tan Pad for Wizard Cutting and Embossing System or something similar.

Title: Six variations on 'hello' and 'hi' Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library and have collected hundreds of different dies over the years. **User Review Content:**
Title: Very decorative but doesn't cut cleanly Review: Cottage Cutz sells an amazing variety of decorative dies. This particular example, the Carousel Silhouette die yields four pieces of paper: the carousel silhouette which measures about 3.5 inches in width; and three pony cut-outs. Text-weight (60 lb) paper seems to yield the cleanest cut. When I attempted to cut regular cardstock (80 lb) with this die, I had to finish the cut with my trusty #11 X-Acto blade. Most Cottage Cutz dies come with a thin piece of sticky-backed foam that you fit over the die face. That's all the preparation that is necessary to use their dies. I attempted to cut this die with my Sizzix Grand Calibur machine, but it didn't yield a completely clean cut, even when I used a shim. The glitter card stock that I used for the ponies was especially resistant to being cut with this die. Please see customer image above for an example of a birthday greeting card that was made with this die.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Other border punching systems work more precisely Review: I have a Tonic Studios Border Punch System with nine interchangeable punches, but I find it very difficult to line up my paper so that each punched-out element is aligned properly with the previous element. Another problem with this system is that the punches wiggle around in the border system, also making alignment difficult. The advantage to the Tonic Studios system is that you can use many different punches with the same border guide. However, I find the Fiskars border punches, e.g. Fiskars 12-23367097 Border Punch Sunburst and Martha Stewart edgers e.g.Martha Stewart Edger Floral Lace much easier to align and use on my greeting card edges. Martha Stewart border punches have matching corner punches, e.g. Martha Stewart Pansy Edge Punch Around the Page, so you can decorate all the way around a sheet of paper. I haven't tried out the corner punches yet because I usually just punch a border on one edge of my card.

Title: Good brand - good color Review: My small Archival Ink sepia pad finally dried up, and I ordered this jumbo-size pad. The advantage to its size is that I can ink up a whole stamp at once, instead of tapping various portions of the stamp to the smaller pad. If you like to use a brayer to color your backgrounds (see customer image of a sympathy card where I used a brayer to add sepia ink to the embossed background), this pad is sized just right. The Archival Inks dry waterproof, so I can use them in conjunction with watercolors. I like the sepia color better than black for baby stamps and flowers, or any stamp where I'm going to be painting the inked image with pastel colors. Sepia and black are the two ink colors that I can't do without.

Title: Nice 3-D Christmas card die Review: Please see customer image above for an example of a card where I used the Spellbinders layered poinsettia dies to decorate a Christmas card. **User Review Content:**
Title: This glue never dries Review: I mounted a picture on a card, using Memory Mount glue, then pressed it under a weight overnight. Imagine my surprise when I lifted the weight in the morning and the card came with it. It was relatively easy to separate everything because the glue was still tacky. It had never dried. In order to remove the excess glue from my picture mount, I had to resort to a craft knife. 'Memory Mount' advertises itself as 'Archival quality,' 'acid free,' and 'non caustic.' If you are looking for a glue that stays tacky for a long time, it might be just the product for you. Its tackiness reminded me of a wad of bublegum I had to scrape off the seat edge at the last theatre I attended. Unfortunately, I was looking for a glue that dried hard so 'Memory Mount' was a bad experience for me. It does dry clear, which is good.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Greeting cards from napkins and toilet paper Review: This book is an absolute hoot. Among the more than 45 projects by this HGTV `Queen of Crafting' are greeting cards made from toilet paper. Okay, partially made from toilet paper (see "Molded Tissue Cards")--and they are really cute! Even though this book is only partially concerned with greeting cards, it contains some of the best and newest (and sometimes, weirdest) ideas for crafting cards that I have yet seen. In addition to cards, the author also teaches her readers how to make paper napkin rings, mobiles, gift boxes, picture frames, coasters, and even working clocks crafted from paper bags. Each project is divided into illustrated steps, and several variations of the finished product are shown. The materials list for each project tends to be shorter than in similar books. You don't have to go out and buy fifteen different doodads and gizmos in order to complete a single card. Merely arm yourself with card stock, glue, ink, and maybe a bottle of bleach and follow this author's directions to create your own paper masterpiece. Meanwhile, I'm off to set up my ironing board, rip off a piece of plastic wrap, hunt up an old Christmas napkin...

**User Review Content:**
Title: Lots of cutting and gluing is needed Review: Cottage Cutz sells an amazing variety of decorative dies. This particular example, Autumn Centerpiece yields 18 pieces of paper, and you are going to have to run the die through your die-cutting machine three times in order to cut three candles. This Cottage Cutz die comes with a thin piece of sticky-backed foam that you fit over the die face. That's all the preparation that is necessary to use the die. I cut this die with my Sizzix Grand Calibur machine, and used a metal shim to get a clean cut. You will be doing quite a bit of gluing with your 54 bits of paper (remember, you need to run the die through your machine 3 times). It is quite a bit of fuss, but the end result is very nice. Please see customer image for an example of an A2 (5.5" x 4.25") Thanksgiving greeting card that was made with this die.

Title: Quick Christmas cards Review: I'm a big fan of the Spellbinders Shapeabilities dies, and this particular set of 7 Christmas dies makes it easy to create nice looking greeting cards. Title: Just what I needed to keep my water colors from drying out too soon Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local county libraries and like to use watercolor backgrounds on many of my cards. One of my favorite techniques is to spread colors randomly on a wet sheet of Hot Pressed 140 lb. Aquarelle Arches watercolor paper, then cover the wet paint with Saran Wrap and wrinkle the Saran Wrap. See customer image for examples produced by this technique. One of my problems with this technique was the watercolors would dry before I applied the Saran Wrap. My art teacher recommended Winsor & Newton Water Color Blending Medium to keep the water colors wet until I applied the Saran Wrap, and this product worked perfectly for me. I had to leave the Saran Wrap on the paper for a longer period of time, because the water colors took longer to dry, but the blending medium yielded beautiful results.

Title: Almost exactly what I was looking for Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library. I bought these Action Wobble Springs to make my cards more three-dimensional (see customer image above for a Halloween card I made with one of these springs). The springs are very easy to use: pull the paper backing off of one side of the spring and stick the transparent remainder to your object (I had to trim quite a bit of the sticky transparency away from my object, as it was smaller than the backing). Peel the paper backing off of the bottom of the spring and stick the remaining transparent circle to your card. There were two minor issues with these springs: (1) The springs are too stiff to allow the object to wobble, although they hold it away from the card front very well. (2) The transparent circle on the bottom of the spring has advertising text on it that I had to cut away because it didn't fit with the card's theme. If your object is bigger than the backing, you won't have to worry about this.

Title: A border punch that is easy to use Review: I own a couple of Martha Stewart border punches, as well as several Fiskars border punches, and of the two brands I'd give Fiskars a higher mark. Their tools punch more cleanly. I often have problems getting a cleanly punched border from the Martha Stewart systems, even after I run aluminum foil through them to clean them out. All of the Fiskars punches are easy to line up over a previously punched area, so that you can punch a continuous border. This particular punch makes a pretty vine-and-flower border for a feminine-looking card. It could be used for anything from birthday to wedding cards. **User Review Content:**
Title: A great craft innovation with a couple of minor problems Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and I started out in my hobby using double-sided tape to stick pieces of paper together. When I discovered the Scotch Advanced Tape Glider through one of my craft teachers, I was delighted. It made my projects so much easier to put together. There are only two things I would change if I could: (1) As the roll of tape gets toward the end, it is harder and harder to use. (2) Putting a new roll of tape onto the glider is quite a fiddly process. I have wrecked whole rolls of tape in my efforts to place the roll properly on the glider. In spite of these two drawbacks, I'll never go back to the regular double-sided tape except under special circumstances.

**User Review Content:**
Title: A very necessary item for die-cuts Review: I have to replace my Spellbinders Grand Calibur Cutting Plate on the average of once a year, and in prior years had to buy a package that included the base plate and embossing plate along with the cutting plate. I am so glad I can now buy the cutting plate by itself. I make around 250 greeting cards per year and sell them to benefit our county libraries, and I like to use lots of die-cuts on my cards. As you will notice, every die that is run through your Grand Calibur die-cutting machine will leave a mark on the cutting plate, especially if you use a metal shim with the more complex dies. By the end of the year, both sides of my cutting plate are looking pretty shabby and sometimes the left-over marks rub off on the new piece of paper that I'm cutting. I have to wonder if the cutting plate were made of a more impervious or heavier plastic, whether I would have to replace it as often.

**User Review Content:**
Title: It works but... Review: I bought this Uchida 90G-C Marvy Jewel Picker at the same time I also purchased a Wax Rhinestone Picker Pencil---by Pixiheart, so I was able to compare the two products head-to-head. The wax pencil did a better job of picking up and holding small rhinestones, AND it was half again as cheap as this product. Plus, when the pencil loses its adhesion, I can sharpen it with a regular pencil sharpener, and it starts to pick up small objects just as if it were new, again. I don't know of a way of 'refurbishing' this Marvy product. I was using tweezers to pick up small rhinestones and place them on my greeting cards, and both the Marvy Jewel Picker and the Rhinestone Picker Pencil work better than tweezers, and I am able to place my rhinestones much more precisely. However, I would definitely recommend the wax picker pencil over this Marvy Jewel Picker.

Title: I was expecting heavier plastic Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and I use this stencil to create backgrounds for various types of cards. To tell you the truth, I was expecting the stencil to be made of heavier, more rigid plastic when I purchased it. The actual plastic is quite thin and flexible. Plus one of the letters in the word 'Art' was not completely cut and I had to finish the job with my trusty X-Acto #11 blade. According to the advertising that comes with the stencil, you can use it with spray ink, sponged ink, bleach, or some chalks. Crafter's Workshop also has a website where you can go for more ideas on how to use their stencils. I use this stencil with spray paint, and because of the fragile nature of the plastic I don't try to clean the paint from the stencil. I'm not sure how many times I'm going to be able to use this stencil before it clogs up with paint.

**User Review Content:**
Title: I was expecting heavier plastic Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and I have created a birthday card and a get well card that are decorated with underwater scenes. I use this stencil to create the background for my quilled fish, fish stickers, fish buttons, and fish stamps. To tell you the truth, I was expecting the stencil to be made of heavier, more rigid plastic when I purchased it. The actual plastic is quite flexible and tends to move a bit, especially the longer cuts such as the stems, when I apply ink over it, even though I have the edges firmly taped to my paper. In fact, the second time I used it I noticed that one little plastic strip had already broken loose. According to the advertising that comes with the stencil, you can use it with spray ink, sponged ink, bleach, or some chalks. Crafter's Workshop also has a website where you can go for more ideas on how to use their stencils.

Title: A very elegant corner die Review: Cottage Cutz sells an amazing variety of decorative dies. This particular die makes quite an elegant corner for a variety of different cards, including wedding, friendship, and birthday. Please see customer image above for a birthday card that I decorated with this die. I used my Spellbinder's Grand Calibur die cutting machine for this die, and I had trouble getting a clean cut on regular cardstock, until I inserted a shim (an extra piece of paper to press the cardstock down into the die) between the plate and the cardstock. I wish these corner dies came in pairs, with one die the mirror-image of the other, so that I could place a die-cut in opposite corners of the card. You can't just flip the die-cut over to get matching corners, as one side of the cut is rounded and the other side is flat.

Title: Works just as well as the non-spray Stazon Cleaner Review: I've bought other rubber stamp cleaners that wouldn't work at all on permanent or archival ink, which is really annoying since solvent, dye-based inks (the cheap ones, at least) will wash off with water. **User Review Content:**
Title: A waste of money Review: I bought this mini iron to use on ribbons for greeting card crafting. These are the problems I have with it: -The cord is only 56" long and the enclosed directions forbid the use of an extension cord. -The directions also state that this product should be used with an ironing board. One of the reasons I bought this mini iron was to avoid having to set up the ironing board. I ignored this particular instruction, and used a cloth napkin on a wooden table as my 'ironing board'--a low wooden table, since the iron's cord is so short. -Even though I let the mini iron heat up for several minutes, it didn't perform efficiently. My ribbon still had wrinkles after I finished ironing it. There is no light that goes on when the iron is hot enough, and nothing in the enclosed directions states how long it takes for the iron to heat up to its working temperature. I would have thought that five minutes should have been more than enough time for this mini iron to reach maximum temperature. My advice to potential buyers: don't waste your money on this mini crafting iron.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Boy, did these dies turn out to be useful! Review: One of my biggest gripes against decorative die manufacturers (such as Spellbinders) is that they don't size their dies to fit on standard American card sizes such as A2 (4.25"x5.5") or A7 (5"x7"). One die that I really wanted was a mat for my A2 cards. The large rectangle (4"x5.25") in this set from Die-Namics cuts perfect mats for A2 cards, and it's my most-used die. The squiggly rectangle makes a nice frame that fits within the mat (see customer image for a sample friendship card that uses these dies plus the middle rectangle). The smaller rectangles (2.5"x3.75" and 2.25"x3.5") also make nice frames within the A2 mat. I haven't used the round dies yet but the smallest dies make neat labels (I print my text on the computer, then center and tape the die over the print and run it through my Spellbinders Grand Calibur Die Cutting Machine. These dies are a bit pricey, but they're worth it to me. They come on a magnetized sheet for easy storage.

Title: Paper-crafting essential Review: Before I discovered these micro pop dots from All Night Media, I was cutting up the quarter-inch adhesive squares from Scrapbook Adhesives, in order to fasten very small decorations to my greeting cards. That was hard on my scissors, and a bit frustrating because I still couldn't cut the squares into really small pieces. These micro dots solved my problem, and 'pop up' small decorations on my cards, giving them a three-dimensional quality. See customer image above for an example of a birthday card that has 15 micro dots adhering to the lizards' feet and tails. These dots aren't perfect. They're a bit hard to pry up. I finally developed a method of squeezing down the matrix around a dot while simultaneously prying up the dot with my fingernail. Each card contains 544 pop dots 1/8" diameter x 1/16" thick.

Title: Useful Christmas embossing folders Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local libraries and these two embossing folders, Ornate Swirls and Winter Words add a nice dimension to the background of my A2 (5.5" x 4.25") Christmas card faces. Please see customer image of a Christmas card I made using the Ornate Swirls embossing folder.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Pretty die but card requires non-standard envelope Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and this heart die is the first of the 'Flip-its' from Sizzix that I have tried. I ran this die through my Sizzix Big Shot machine. The directions that came with the die showed how to set up the 'sandwich' of two cutting pads plus paper plus this die, although they aren't specific for the Heart flip-its die. My problem came after I cut the paper when I had to fold it into the correct shape. There are no directions that show how to fold the paper into a card with the heart cut-out in the right place. Luckily, there is a video on YouTube that demonstrates how to fold the paper for a Sizzix Flip-its die, although it uses a die other than the Heart flip-its. Just search for 'Sizzix flip-its' on the web and click on the YouTube video. Another problem is the size of the card, which doesn't fit into any of the standard envelope sizes that I use for my other greeting cards. Once folded, the card measures about 5"x5" (depending on how well you folded it). However, 5.5"x5.5" envelopes can be purchased at paper supply stores (I got mine at paper-paper.com) which can be used with these flip-its cards. Please see customer images above for a birthday card that I made using this Heart Flip-Its die from Sizzix.

**User Review Content:**
Title: A cute die plus instructions on how to use it Review: The 'Tattered Lace' brand sells some very elegant dies and 'Rambling Rose' is one of them. I make and sell cards to benefit our local library, and cards decorated with Tattered Lace dies sell out almost as soon as I put them out on the card rack. Cardstock (80 lb.) yields a clean cut when I use the CottageCutz Universal Shim Plate Die Cuts in combination with this die. Please see customer image for an example of an A2 (5.5"x4.25") birthday card that I made with this die. This is the 5th issue of the "Tattered Lace" magazine which has the 4"x2.5" Rambling Rose die attached to it. Inside there are illustrated instructions on how to use this particular die, and many of the instructions also include other Tattered Lace dies such as the 'Basket Full of Delight' die. All of the instructions come with step-by-step color photographs. Some of the other dies featured in projects in this issue are the 'Mini Blooms' die set, the 'Mannequin' die set, the 'Lacy Chrysanthemum' die set, the 'Frippery & Frills' dies, the 'Rocking Horse die, the 'Venetian Swag' die set, the 'Doily Delights' die, the 'Kensington' die set the 'Venetian Floral' die set, the 'Venetian Fern' die, and the 'Chantilly Rose' die. All come with step-by-step tutorials. You will have to purchase these dies separately. A really cute special feature shows how to make a fairground carousel box using the carousel template in the magazine, the Rocking Horse die, the Venetian Swag die set, pink polka dot cardstock (a free download), pink polka dot organza ribbon, ultra fine glitter, and faux pearls. This magazine also includes six pages of patterned, double-sided backing papers, mainly in shades of pink, green, and lavender.

Title: Trendy cutting dies for greeting cards Review: Please see customer image above for an example of a card where I used the small bird and large birdcage dies to decorate a friendship card. If you are going to emboss using a Cuttlebug and the Shapeabilities Spellbinders dies, you will also need to purchase a tan embossing mat which is sold separately from the Cuttlebug machine.

I usually use them in groups of four because they are relatively small (see customer image for an example of a wedding card made with these stickers.) Each sticker is embellished by a crystal rhinestone. You simply peel the cakes off of the clear plastic sheet inside the package, and stick them to your card or scrapbook page. NOTE: I didn't have any problems with these stickers falling apart, as did the previous reviewer.

Title: I tested this product against Detachol Review: I bought this product because it was a bit cheaper than Detachol Adhesive Remover, which I been using for years to remove everything from bandage adhesive to pine sap. Somehow I managed to get some big blobs of pine sap on the hood and windshield of my car, so I gave Un-du and Detachol a chance to remove the sap. I applied these adhesive removers to paper towels and went to work on the pine sap. Result: Detachol won hands-down. I'll save the Un-du for the easy jobs, but from now on Detachol, in spite of its higher price, is the adhesive remover for me.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Nice ripple effect, but don't use on heavy paper Review: If you use these decorative scissors on 80 lb. card stock or paper of a lesser weight, you should be fine, but when I attempted to cut an edge on Petaloo - Glitter Paper Sheets - Red White Pink and Chocolate these scissors chewed the paper, but didn't cut an edge. If I tried to use extra pressure on the scissors, they locked up and wouldn't cut at all. Another not-so-great feature is the short length of the cutting blades on the Fiskars Paper Edgers. They will only cut 2.5" at a time, so you have to keep lining up blades to the cut edge, if you want to cut a longer length. The decorative-edge scissors that I use most often are Fiskars 98987097 Softgrip Pinking Fabric Shears, which are quite a bit more expensive, but they cut a longer edge, and you can use them on heavier paper or cloth. Unfortunately, there isn't a large variety of edge designs in this product line.

Title: A great long-haired cat grooming tool Review: My Maine Coon got sick every time we took him to the groomer, so I bought a pet shaver but he bolts out of the room whenever I turn it on. So I asked the owners of a Maine Coon cattery how they removed the clumps of fur from their show cats, and they told me to get a seam ripper. This small seam ripper from Dritz is perfect for eliminating the clumped fur on my cat. I've tried other brands of seam ripper, but the blades aren't sharp enough. This seam ripper fits perfectly into my hand. For some reason, the blade on this small seam ripper seems sharper than the one on the longer model. It you want to try this technique on your cat, be sure not to pull too hard on the clump. Otherwise, you might end up cutting into skin

**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**

- Main Category: Office Products
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Crafting, Paper & Paper Crafts, Punches

**User Review Content:**
Title: Easy to store and use Review: I want to compare this Bostich 3-Hole Punch to my old Acco 3-hole punch with the swinging lever. I have used the latter product for a few decades and it worked well, but now the rubber tray on the bottom that holds the discarded paper 'holes' keeps falling off. The Bostich model also has a rubber or plastic tray, but it seems to fit more tightly to the metal punch. Incidentally, the Bostich model is advertised as 'all metal' on the box, but the tray for the discarded paper 'holes' is either rubber or flexible plastic. The Bostich model is also advertised as punching up to 12 sheets of paper at a time. I was able to punch 8 pages of typing paper comfortably. If you really do have to punch multiple sheets on a consistent basis, you might want to go with a more heavy-duty punch that has a lever arm. I was also able to punch holes in a fairly stiff piece of cardboard with the Bostich, which is important to me as I store craft dies on cardboard sheets in a three-ring binder. In summary, this Bostich 3-hole punch is easy to use although if I'm trying to punch multiple sheets of paper at a time, I sometimes have trouble fitting them neatly into the narrow slot under the punches. ***product supplied by vendor for testing and review purposes***

**User Review Content:**
Title: Good labelling dies for greeting cards Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library and have collected hundreds of different dies over the years. I have found that Die-Namics dies work with all major die-cutting tools on the market. They are usually a good size for A2 greeting cards (5.5" x 4.25") and cut very well on my Spellbinders Grand Calibur machine. I personally think they cut better than the Spellbinder dies. I have used at least one of my Die-Namics dies well over a hundred times and it still cuts sharply. These pierced fishtail dies can be used to decorate a variety of different A2 (5.5" x 4.25") greeting cards, including birthday and graduation cards (see customer image for a birthday card I made from one of these dies). I should have paid more attention to the length of these fishtail dies. I used the 3rd and 4th largest fishtail dies to make the card in the customer image, and they took up the whole length of the A2 card. I probably won't use the biggest two dies at all except for A7 or larger greeting cards.

**Product Description:** ['Jacquard Marbling Kit contains one 0.5 oz bottle each of 6 Non-Toxic marbling colors in red, yellow, blue, green, black and white along with a 5 oz pack of alum mordant and a 2 oz pack of methocel. Kit with assorted marbling colors is ideal for professionals, yet easy enough to use for beginners to create beautiful, unique papers for bookbinding, collage or gift wrapping. This value pack is also included with the complete instructions.', "Use Jacquard's Marbling Kit to make beautiful patterned fabric or gift wrapping paper as unique as you are. Historically, the art of marbling paper has been associated with the craft of bookbinding. This technique involves creating a multi-colored pattern of paint that floats on the surface of a gel-like medium. Once you have mixed the paint and medium, you can lay your paper or fabric on the surface of the liquid to pick up the floating paint and transfer the design. This kit is designed to be used and enjoyed by professionals and beginners alike. The kit contains six 1/2-oz bottles of marbling colors (black, blue, green, red, yellow, and white). Also includes methocel marbling medium, alum sizing, and complete instructions. (Note: paper and fabric are not included in this kit.) For ages 12 and up. For over 30 years, Jacquard has been the leading manufacturer of artist quality textile, mixed media and craft products. Our products include textile paints, dyes, fabric art markers, screen inks and craft kits."]


**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**
- Brand: Jacquard
- Main Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Fabric & Textile Paints, Fabric Decorating

**User Review Content:**
Title: Marbling starter kit that needs to be supplemented Review: This kit has been assembled for those of us who would like to try our hand at marbling paper or cloth. It contains: * Six oz. bottles of marbling colors (red, blue, yellow, black, green, white). Each bottle is topped with a dropper, so that you can squeeze the color directly onto the size (the gelatinous substance that the colors float on top of--if you're lucky). The white color that came with this kit was grainy. I suspect it had partially dried in the bottle. The black and green wanted to sink, but this tendency could have been due to the humidity or temperature. Size (the gel that supports the colors) is very temperamental * 5 oz. Alum Mordant--this is what you spray onto your paper to prepare it for marbling. Otherwise, the colors won't stick to the paper * 2 oz. Methocel--Blend this ingredient with warm water to make your size. I didn't use the methocel that came with this kit. I preferred making my size with Carrageenan, which had to be bought separately * Instructions on how to prepare your cloth or paper, and size. You are also instructed on how to make some of the most common marbling patterns such as `stone,' `get-gel,' or `rake Nonpareil.' Finally, you are taught how to pick up your pattern on your paper or fabric, rinse it, and then clean up afterwards (the hardest part!) There are items that this Jacquard Marbling Kit does not include, which you will have to purchase or make separately: * Paper. I have successfully marbled 140 lb. hot-pressed watercolor paper, and 110 lb. white card stock (for laser printer), after treating it with the alum mordant * A pan in which to float your size (I used a small plastic kitty litter pan) * A board to support your marbled paper while rinsing off the excess color * Various jugs to mix up your alum mordant and size (I used plastic milk bottles) * Paper drying rack (I used wire shelving, but non-rusting screens would work. You can even hang your paper to dry over a clothesline) * A board (I used an old wooden ruler) to skim the crud off of your size. You can reuse your size if you skim it between marbling patterns * Whisks, combs, and rakes to draw your patterns in the colors floating on the size. These can be purchased separately or constructed out of T-pins and strips of wood * Lots and lots of old newspaper to protect your working surface, clean up splatters, and skim off your size (wrap strips of it around your skimming board) Marbling is complicated, but fun, and you can make some seriously beautiful patterns on your cloth or paper. I use my marbled paper to fashion greeting cards. I strongly suggest that you supplement the instructions that come with this Jacquard Marbling kit. I can recommend Diane and Paul Maurer's books: An introduction to carrageenan and watercolor marbling and Marbling: A Complete Guide to Creating Beautiful Patterned Papers and Fabrics. A couple of other, less detailed texts are: Gabriele Grünebaum's How to Marbleize Paper: Step-by-Step Instructions for 12 Traditional Patterns (Other Paper Crafts); and a 19-page guide by Christine Cox, "Paper Marbling Patterns and How-To" from [...] (where I also bought most of my marbling supplies).

Title: Nice for layering, but hard to glue stuff on top of it Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library and go through a lot of card stock in the course of a year. I was looking for a glittery silver cardstock to use for layering, and this Duo-tone glitter card stock from American Crafts does add bling to my cards. My only problem with it: it's hard to glue anything on top of it as the heavy glitter makes for an uneven surface. Tape didn't work and neither did regular glue. I finally had to resort to hot glue. I personally wouldn't use this paper as a card base. It's too thick and unwieldy. It does layer nicely using hot glue. I wouldn't run it through my die cutter either, because of the uneven surface. See customer image for a birthday card that I layered with this card stock.

Title: The 'CONGRATULATIONS' die doesn't cut completely and is too large for A2 greeting cards Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library and have collected hundreds of different dies over the years. I have found that Die-Namics dies work with all major die-cutting tools on the market. They are a good size for A2 greeting cards (5.5" x 4.25") and cut very well on my Spellbinders Grand Calibur machine. I personally think they cut better than the Spellbinder dies. I have used at least one of my Die-Namics dies well over a hundred times and it still cuts sharply. Having said that Die-Namics dies work on A2 cards, I need to point out that the 'Congratulations' die is too large to fit on an A2 card. Furthermore, it doesn't cut completely. You will have to finish cutting the tops of the letters. See customer image for a graduation card I made from these dies, excepting the 'Congratulations' die.

Title: Cuts well and nice size for an A2 greeting card Review: The Spellbinders Filigree Vase is a useful die for all sorts of greeting cards. This particular set consists of two dies: the solid vase, which measures about 3 1/4" high and about 1 5/8" at its greatest width. The filigree vase die is slightly smaller. Note that the filigree vase does not have a cutting edge around the outside of the die. I got clean cuts with card stock (80 lb) paper. Please see customer image for an example of a Sympathy greeting card that was made with the filigree vase die. I hand-cut around the outer edge of the filigree vase to free it from the excess paper. Then I traced the vase on lighter-colored card stock, hand-cut it and pasted it to the back of the filigree vase, which gave me a nice two-toned effect.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Doesn't cover as well as other Smooch Accent Inks Review: Smooch Accent Inks give better coverage than marking pens and the applicator allows you to color in very fine details. The ink is opaque, so you can use them over colored cardstock, although Gold Lam takes several coats before you get good coverage--see 'Birthday' on the birthday card in the customer image. One of the 'features' I dislike about marking pens (the cheap ones, at least) is that the color is absorbed by the paper and spreads into areas I don't want it to go. You don't have to worry about spreading with these inks: they go on like enamel. Maybe that's why the bottles are designed to look like fingernail polish containers. I also tried floating the inks on water to see if I could create marbled paper with them. I used 110 lb. cardstock, and the colors did take, but they were very light and their characteristic sheen didn't come through. Possibly glossy cardstock would serve as a better base for marbling with these Smooch Accent Inks. I won't be throwing away my regular marbling colors any time soon. In summary, I can highly recommend this product to add color to greeting cards, especially small, stamped images, and decorative edging. **Product Description:** ['Tonic Studios verso corner dies are the perfect die to add a touch of detail to the corners of cards or scrapbooking projects. All of the corners are verso styled meaning the inner and outer cut are separate, so the corner detail can be cut straight into the or can be cut out and layered up.']

**Product Features:**
- The first installment of Tonic Studios Verso Corner Dies
- Pack is verso styled meaning the inner and outer cut are different
- A total of 8 dies in this set
- Can be used as corner decoration or as a standalone die

**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**
- Brand: TONIC STUDIOS
- Main Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Die-Cuts, Die-Cutting & Embossing, Scrapbooking & Stamping

**User Review Content:**
Title: Versatile corner dies, but could have been sized a bit better Review: These corner dies come in four sets of two: each set contains the corner die plus an outer cutting edge die. You can either cut a decorative pattern into the corner of your card stock without using the outer cutting edge, or else you can place the outer cutting edge around its partner die (I used a piece of tape to hold them together) and cut out the whole corner, and place the cut-out on the corner of your card stock. See customer image for an example of the latter method that I used to make an A2 (5.5" x 4.25") Anniversary card. Note how the wings on the small butterflies within the pattern pop up. I covered them with silver paper. The two smaller sets of dies are suitable for A2 cards, but you will need to use the larger two sets of dies on an A7 or larger greeting card. Even the smaller die sets are not exactly sized for an A2 card, and you will get a bit of overlap in the pattern along the width of the card. I do wish die manufacturers would pay a bit more attention to the standard card sizes their customers usually work with. These dies are really made for square cards--popular in Great Britain, but not here in the United States because we get charged extra postage if we try to mail a square card.

**Product Title:** Spellbinders S5-181 Borderabilities A2 Bracket Borders Die Templates

**Product Price:** $14.85

**Product Description:** ["As a scrapbooking and craft enthusiast, Stacey Caron identified the market need for one die cutting system that could function in place of several existing tools. She wanted a comprehensive craft tool that would be universal with manufacturers' existing products, cut, emboss, be portable and be sturdy enough to withstand the test of time. As a result of Stacey's entrepreneurial spirit and her husband Jeff's creative ingenuity, the Wizard Universal Craft Tool was born, along with Spellbinders patented technology Die Templates for cutting, embossing and stenciling. Innovations continue with the Grand Calibur machine and the Presto Punch machine, the first automatic punching and embossing system. Spellbinders continues to demonstrate ingenuity, integrity and trend setting ideas, while remaining a family-owned, customer service oriented business. Spellbinders Paper Arts entered the craft and hobby market in 2003 with the introduction of the Wizard Universal Craft Tool and now has more than 250 patented and patent pending products under the trade names of Nest abilities, Edge abilities, Shape abilities, Border abilities and Nesties. The Bracket Borders One template set is a wonderful complement to the Card Creator dies template series. This seven die template set features bracket shaped edges with intricate details. There are four different edge designs and three decorative inserts. All make continuous cuts and decorative edges, by matching up registration marks on the ends of the die template. Spellbinders Border abilities dies cut, emboss and stencil with a single die template. Approximate die template sizes are: 6 x 5/8 inches, 6 x 1/4 inches and 6 x 1/8 inches."]

**Product Features:**
- Bracket Borders One templates have intricate details for cards or any paper projects

Title: Mix and Match these border dies on A2 Greeting Cards Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and these border dies add an elegant touch to almost any type of A2 (5.5" x 4.25") card. - Folder for embossing paper, parchment, cardstock, and more

**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**

- Price Range: Under $10

**User Review Content:**
Title: Can be used for many types of greeting cards Review: The only limitation to the Cuttlebug embossing folders is their size: this hearts folder will emboss a piece of cardstock that fits nicely onto an A2 (4.25"x5.5") card. But embossed paper is usually used for layering, so the size limitation might not be as important as it seems. I can also emboss with my Xyron Creatopia Machine, and since its embossing system consists of a set of two rollers (as opposed to the Cuttlebug's folder), I can emboss paper of any length. However, Xyron's machine has very few embossing patterns, whereas Cuttlebug has something for almost every type of card (except maybe sympathy--I use a tree embossing pattern for my sympathy cards). The hearts folder can be used for wedding, anniversary, friendship, 'missing you,' and even new baby cards. It has both intaglio and relief embossing, and is lots of fun to color (especially with chalk). I like to use a printed transparency film over the pattern to carry my message. The Cuttlebug is basically a set of two rollers that press the folder pattern (back and front) into a piece of paper as the paper and folder are fed through the rollers. It's a simple concept, and the Cuttlebug performs it really well.

Title: Makes good die cuts Review: I use the 12x12" Bazzill Basics green assortment for die cutting--mainly stems and leaves. It is a good weight for producing a clean die cut. It also produces a crisp stamped image on the reverse of the textured side. I generally use the 8.5"x11" inch Bazzill card stock for my card base. One sheet will produce 2 A2 cards (4.25"x5.5"). The only problem with Bazzill card stock is that the grain runs the wrong way if I am trying to print 2 A2 cards from one 8.5"x11" sheet. This sometimes makes it difficult to fold the card in half. If the card stock is heavily textured, I may have to clean up the fold with a file or a small pair of scissors.

**Product Title:** Pebeo Drawing Gum, 45-Milliliter (33000)

**Product Price:** $8.58

**Product Description:** ['Drawing Gum is a peelable rubber solution used to keep areas colour free when using ink, watercolour or gouache. It can be applied using a brush or a pen on the surfaces of the drawing that require to be masked. The colours may be applied once the Drawing Gum is dry (10 to 15 minutes). To reveal the plain paper beneath, the Drawing Gum is simply rubbed off using a finger or an eraser once the colors are completely dry.']

**Product Features:**
- Drawing gum in 45ml bottle
- Dryes within about 15 minutes depending on the quantity used and surface
- Can be applied on paper, bristol board and cardboard
- Clean brushes with soapy water before drying


**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**
- Brand: Pebeo
- Main Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Painting, Painting, Drawing & Art Supplies, Paints
- Price Range: Under $10

**User Review Content:**
Title: The best masking fluid that I've tried Review: I was using a white masking fluid until my watercolor teacher let me try some of her Pebeo, which goes on gray. The color makes it easier to see where it's being applied. It was far superior to the white stuff. Here is the method she taught me: (1) Use an inexpensive brush (2) Dip the brush in soapy water (3) Dip the brush in Pebeo and apply it to your watercolor where you want to save the white areas. (4) Clean the brush after you're done. The application of soapy water prior to the Pebeo keeps the brush from stiffening up. The Pebeo Drawing Gum dries at about the same speed as the white stuff and it took about the same amount of effort to peel it back off of the watercolor once it dried and had been painted over.

Title: Lovely on spring-themed cards Review: I actually think this one-piece die more resembles lilies-of-the-valley than bluebells (except for the narrow leaves), but in either case there are many different types of greeting cards this die would enhance. See customer image for a friendship card that I made with this die. It also works well on sympathy and Easter cards. In order to color the flowers differently than the leaves, you can either do two cuts (one in green and the other in say, white) then cut the flower shapes and paste them onto the green die-cut. I took the easier route and painted the flowers white using an opaque acrilic paint (titanium white). I've purchased many dies from Cottage Cutz, and this is the first one that did not come with the stick-on plastic square that goes over the cutting edges. It works just fine without the plastic, though.

**Product Description:** ['CLEARSNAP-Smooch Accent Ink. Use on paper; cardstock; clay; glass and much more. Great for detail accents and layering. The bottle topper doubles as an easy to hold applicator with brush tip. Acid free; archival and fast drying. This package contains one 0.3-ounce/9ml bottle with applicator cap. - Adding colorful pearlescent accents is easy using the applicator included in each bottle

**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**

- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Ink Pads, Scrapbooking & Stamping, Stamps & Ink Pads

**User Review Content:**
Title: Excellent for highlighting details on greeting cards Review: I watched an online demonstration of crafters decorating greeting cards with these inks and bought a set of pearlized colors which included 'sugarberry' (dries to a medium purple - see customer image for an example of an Anniversary card that I decorated with Sugarberry Smooch Pearlized Accent Ink on the body of the rocket.) They give better coverage than marking pens and the applicator allows you to color in very fine details. The ink is opaque, so you can use them over colored cardstock. One of the 'features' I dislike about marking pens (the cheap ones, at least) is that the color is absorbed by the paper and spreads into areas I don't want it to go. You don't have to worry about spreading with these inks: they go on like enamel. Maybe that's why the bottles are designed to look like fingernail polish containers. I also tried floating the inks on water to see if I could create marbled paper with them (as is shown in the demo video). I used 110 lb. cardstock, and the colors did take, but they were very light and their characteristic sheen didn't come through. Possibly glossy cardstock would serve as a better base for marbling with these Smooch Accent Inks. I won't be throwing away my regular marbling colors any time soon. In summary, I can highly recommend this product to add color to greeting cards, especially small, stamped images, and decorative edging.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Perfectly placed stamped images--Amazing!! Review: I saw the Mini Misti Stamp Tool demonstrated in a YouTube video, where the demonstrator had to restamp an image because she didn't get it dark enough the first time, and I said, "That's the tool for me!" I can't think how much ink and paper I've wasted over the years on bad stampings, where one or two parts of the image didn't show up very well. I've even finished a few of those partially inked images with a pen. Now, the Mini Misti gives me the power to over-stamp as many times as I want in order to get a perfect image. Yay!!! This tool also allows for perfect placement of your stamp (or stamps) on the card stock. Please see customer image of an A2 (5.5" x 4.25") friendship card with four stamped images that I made with this tool. The Mini Misti is very easy to use. I didn't even have to read the instructions, and there are lots of demonstrations out on YouTube. I only wish I hadn't bought so many wood-backed stamps over the years, because they can't be used with this amazing tool.

**User Review Content:**
Title: 'Boo to You' is a useful addition to my Cuttlebug embossing folders Review: The only limitation to the Cuttlebug embossing folders is their size: this happy birthday folder will emboss a layer of paper that fits nicely onto 4.25"x5.5" piece of cardstock (size A2). Since embossed paper is usually used for layering, so the size limitation might not be as important as it seems. I can also emboss with my Xyron Creatopia Machine 12-Inch-Includes 25ft Permanent Adhesive, and since its embossing system consists of a set of two rollers (as opposed to the Cuttlebug's folder), I can emboss paper of any length. However, Xyron's machine has very few embossing patterns, whereas Cuttlebug has something for almost every type of card (except maybe sympathy--I use a tree embossing pattern for my sympathy cards). The birthday folder is the one I use most often. It has both intaglio and relief embossing, and is lots of fun to color (especially with chalk). Please see customer image of an A7 (5" x 7") Halloween card made with the 'Boo to You' embossing folder.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Sticks in the 'down' position Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and I bought this McGill Birthday Party punch mainly to decorate my card interiors. There are nine separate shapes that come out every time you use the punch (if you're lucky): a balloon and string (2); a candle; a cupcake; a present; a birthday hat; a small star; and a couple of little parallelograms (one of which I suppose you could use to show the 'glint' on the balloon). Unfortunately, this punch turned out to be very difficult to use. It works quite stiffly, even on the lightest-weight paper, and more often than not, it sticks in the 'down' position, and I have to flip it over and beat on it with a screwdriver . I have tried to run both wax paper and aluminum foil through the punch, as I heard these are remedies for a sticking punch. The aluminum foil helped a bit, but I still have to rap the punch on the table to get it to unstick. See customer image for an example of a Birthday card I decorated, using cut objects from this punch. Not recommended.

Coordinates with other sets in the CARD Creator Collection. The Curved Matting Basics templates coordinates with other CARD collections for other matting options. Spellbinders Nest abilities Card Creator brings a simple and unique solution to multiple crafting projects. The work is all done for you, no more measuring required. Simply...Choose your design, Assemble your pieces, Refine the details and you're Done. Sized in 1/8 inch and 1/4 inch increments, choose the size from our sets for perfectly spaced layers. Approximate die template sizes are: 7/8 x 2-1/8 inches, 1-3/8 x 2-5/8 inches, 1-7/8 x 3-1/8 inches, 2-3/8 x 3-5/8 inches, 2-7/8 x 4-1/8 inches, 3-3/8 x 4-5/8 inches, 3-7/8 x 5-1/8 inches and a 3-3/8 x 1/2 inch small rectangle or 3-7/8 x 1 inch large rectangle."]

- Price Range: $10-$25

**User Review Content:**
Title: It works with the really detailed dies Review: I was having a problem getting a clean cut with some of my really detailed dies, especially the fancy Cottage Cutz dies. This Universal Shim Plate from Cottage Cutz solves the problem of incomplete cuts (see customer image for a card that is decorated with a die where I used this shim). I ran the die and shim through my Spellbinder Grand Calibur die cutting machine, and it was a very tight fit (I was cutting 80 lb. card stock), but it did come through with a clean cut. The directions that come with the shim show how to use it with a Cuttlebug or Big Shot die cutting machine, so you may not even want to use it with your Grand Calibur machine. Next, I tried the shim with my Sizzix Big Shot die cutting machine, using the Sizzlet die "Happy Birthday #3" phrase. This particular Sizzlet always gives me problems with an incomplete cut. However, when I ran it through with the shim and 80 lb. card stock, the phrase cut cleanly. So if you are having problems with incomplete cuts, you might want to give this shim a try. Even with the Big Shot, it was a tight fit using the shim, so be careful not to force your die cutter past its breaking point.

**User Review Content:**
Title: You need one of these to use with the decorative strip dies Review: I've got a Big Shot Die Cutting machine with a pair of 13" Cutting Pads, but I discovered that I also needed one of these extended spacer platforms in order to get my Tim Holtz Sizzix - Decorative Strip Die Butterfly Frenzy to work properly. It's a very sturdy strip of plastic and the strip die works beautifully when sandwiched between the spacer platform and the cutting pads. The one thing I do not like about my Sizzix BigShot is that it takes all sorts of extra parts for cutting anything out of the ordinary such as the butterfly strip die, or a flip card, or a pop-up card. I've got a whole box full of plates and extensions to use with the Big Shot. You are almost better off getting a Silhouette Portrait die cutting machine and hooking it up to your PC. Then, you can cut darn near anything you want without having to buy all of these expensive extra parts.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Very adaptable set of dies Review: Please see customer image above for an example of a card where I used sewing maching, button, and scissors dies in this set to decorate a 'Thank You' card. This is a very adaptable set of dies for decorating your greeting cards, and I've used them for "Thank You," "Mother's Day," and "Birthday" cards, so far. My only problem with this set of dies occurs when I try to remove the embossed and cut cardstock from the button dies. There are a couple of tiny holes where you can insert a pin and push at the cardstock, but the pin also leaves holes in the paper. I wish Spellbinders had made these holes a bit bigger, so I could have used a toothpick to remove the cardstock from the die. I use my Spellbinders Shapeabilities dies with a Cuttlebug machine. The directions on how to use these dies with the Spellbinders Wizard, the Big Kick by Sizzix, and the Cuttlebug by Provocraft come with every set of dies, and they are very clear and easy to follow. If you are going to emboss using a Cuttlebug and the Shapeabilities Spellbinders dies, you will also need to purchase a tan embossing mat such as Spellbinders W-005 12 by 12 Tan Pad for Wizard Cutting and Embossing System.

**Product Description:** ["Cheery Lynn Designs - makers of the world's most beautiful high quality paper cutting dies, tools and inspiration for scrap bookers, card makers and crafters the world over. Cheery Lynn Designs DL112AB small exotic Butterflies #1 W/angel wings: each angel wing has a butterfly mate. These dies are used to cut an exact shape of a full size die cut butterfly related to each die. Simply fold your backing paper, tape the die to the edge of the fold and die cut both layers. Remove and open for a perfect die cut shape in seconds! these dies may also be used to create random dimensional cuts in craft paper or simple decorative- shaped cuts of Butterflies. To create a dimensional die cut, place the die in position to cut on one side of a card and then flip the card to cut the other half of the shape. To keep shape as part of the card, separate the two die cuts slightly to keep the shape as part of the card. You may also glue the butterfly mate to the shape for an attractive surprise when the card is opened."]

Title: Butterfly die cuts are especially appropriate for sympathy cards Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and I use these little butterfly dies all the time to decorate a variety of card types. If I don't know what else to do with the interior of a card, I glue in a butterfly. I think the butterflies are especially appropriate for Sympathy cards, since in many cultures they symbolize the human soul. Please see customer image for an A2 (5.5" x 4.25") Sympathy card that I decorated with a butterfly die cut. I cut these dies with my Spellbinders Grand Calibur machine and got a clean cut on 140 lb. watercolor paper when using a metal shim. Sometimes I add Stickles glitter glue to the butterfly wings for a bit of sparkle (Ranger Stickles Glitter Glue 1/2-Ounce, Diamond is especially useful).

Title: Seems to need parts I don't have Review: I've got a Big Shot Die Cutting machine with a pair of 13" Cutting Pads, but I can't get this die to cut properly. You are almost better off getting a Silhouette Portrait die cutting machine and hooking it up to your PC. Then, you can cut darn near anything you want.

**User Review Content:**
Title: This powder prep bag really works! Review: I always had problems embossing cards because too much of the embossing powder would stick to the card surface (see left-hand example in customer image above). I was sceptical about Inkadinkado Embossing Magic, but bought one anyway because of the good reviews, and by golly it worked! (see right-hand example in customer image above). All I had to do was rub the powder bag onto the card surface before I stamped the image. Next I sprinkled my embossing powder onto the card, tapped off the excess, then heat-embossed the image as usual. The result: a nice, clean image without excess powder all over the place. I like this product!

Title: These dies are nice for masculine-themed birthday cards Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and have quite a few sets of Spellbinder dies. This six-piece 'Sprightly Sprocket' set is quite nice for masculine-theme birthday cards, but I've also used them for graduation cards (see customer image above). It's fun to cut the sprockets in different colors and piece them together with a brad in the center of each sprocket. As with all of the Spellbinder die sets, good directions are included on how to use these dies with Cuttlebug, Big Kick & Big Shot, Spellbinders Wizard and Grand Calibur machines. I usually run them through my Grand Calibur machine. It's a bit difficult to pry the die-cut out of these sprocket dies, but with a little patience you'll get some nice results.

Title: Many decorating options with this colorful twine Review: Greeting cards decorated with colored baker's twine (also called 'fancy floss') are very fashionable, right now. The twine can be used in place of ribbon, or can be strung into patterns as a key component of Spirelli string art. Even though I wince at paying so much for what is essentially colored string, I've managed to accumulate nine different colors. Each of the We R Memory Keepers Sew Easy Fancy Floss packages comes with three different colors of twine. This particular set includes lilac, wintergreen, and coral reef. Other popular uses for fancy floss: use it in place of regular embroidery floss, or to tie buttons onto your greeting cards. I used it for the balloon strings on the graduation card in the customer image.

**User Review Content:**
Title: The best ink pad for embossed paper Review: I generally make and sell between 150 - 200 greeting cards per year, and I like to emboss the backgrounds, and then color them so that the raised pattern stands out. I tried all sorts of ink pads until I finally found this vintage photo Distress Ink pad from Jim Holz. It's advertised as creating "an aged look on papers, fibers, photos & more" which wasn't quite what I was looking for. But it also works very well for coloring a raised pattern after I've run my cardstock through my Cuttlebug with an embossing folder. Please see the customer image for a sympathy card that I embossed with an autumn-themed folder, then colored with the vintage photo Distress Ink pad. The only drawback to using this Distress Ink pad is that it takes a few minutes to dry. The vintage photo color will appear to be dark brown on almost any color of card stock.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Tricky to load, wonderful to use Review: I used to stick my cardstock layers together with double-sided tape until my husband got me a Scotch CAT 085 Advanced Tape Glider with 2 Rolls of 1/4-Inch by 36-Yard Acid Free Tape,Cure Pink for my birthday. Once the tape roll is loaded into this glider (a tricky process), you just pull the trigger and lay down a 1/4" wide line of tape where ever you need it. This process is far easier than trying to measure and cut and place conventional double-sided tape. Putting a refill roll onto the Scotch Advanced Tape Glider requires a bit of patience. I've figured out about ten different ways of doing it incorrectly. Detailed instructions for replacing the refill rolls comes with the glider--it takes 8 steps, and luckily they are illustrated. Follow these steps very carefully, and you shouldn't have any trouble adding your refill rolls (unless you were born with no sense of 3-D geometry like I was).

Title: Not quite what I expected, but okay Review: For some reason (probably because I didn't read the product description carefully) I was expecting a punch to create decorative corners for greeting cards. However, this punch creates decorate corner slots for inserts such as photographs. I used it to create an Easter card (see customer image). Easy-to-follow directions come with the punch, although they are displayed in really small print (English, French, and Spanish). I didn't have any problems following the diagrams and the text. The problem came when I tried to figure out what size of insert would best fit into the four slots I had created. The size of the front of the greeting card determines the size of the insert. You don't really get to choose the size of the insert, as the placement of the corner slots is set by lining up the edges of the card with the plastic extensions on the punch.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Good quality cardstock Review: I use Bazzill Basics 8.5"x11" cardstock for almost all of my greeting cards because it is just the right weight, and there is a wide range of yummy colors to choose from. However, there is one huge problem for those of us who want to make two standard A2 (4.25"x5.5") cards from a single piece of Bazzill Basics stock: the grain runs the wrong way on the paper. When I fold the paper (it doesn't matter whether I'm making a side-fold or a top-fold card) it is a struggle to get it to fold straight, and I often have to cut away little bits of paper that popped up along the fold. If you are printing two A2 cards on one sheet of Bazzill Basic stock, you'll just have to live with the problem of the grain going the wrong way. I still use this paper because I like its weight and the wide range of available colors. This pink dotted Swiss paper makes nice baby girl and Sweet Sixteen greeting cards.

**User Review Content:**
Title: A great ink pad for embossing Review: I generally make and sell between 150 - 200 greeting cards per year, and I like to emboss the backgrounds, and then color them so that the raised pattern stands out. I tried all sorts of ink pads until I finally found this antique linen Distress Ink pad from Jim Holz. It's advertised as creating "an aged look on papers, fibers, photos & more" which wasn't quite what I was looking for. But it also works very well for coloring a raised pattern after I've run my cardstock through my Cuttlebug with an embossing folder. Please see the customer image for a baby card that I embossed with a swirl-themed folder, then colored with the antique linen Distress Ink pad (the background to the main image). The only drawback to using this Distress Ink pad is that it takes a few minutes to dry. The antique linen color will appear to be almost green on yellow or blue card stock.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Comes with minimal directions Review: I use this 2-part rosette die with my Spellbinder's Grand Calibur die-cutting machine, and in order to get a rosette that looks like the one in the illustration, I need to cut two strips from the long die. Luckily the long die just fits on a sheet of 8.5"x11" paper if it is positioned diagonally. This die set makes a very elegant die cut (see customer image for an A7 Get Well greeting card created using this die). I wish the directions that came with it had included instructions for piecing and glueing the rosette. I had difficulties making the paper strips to lie flat while I was glueing them together and getting them to form a circle. The rosette is relatively thick, so you may want to box the resulting greeting card rather than trying to force it into an envelope.

**Product Description:** ["As a scrapbooking and craft enthusiast, Stacey Caron identified the market need for one die cutting system that could function in place of several existing tools. She wanted a comprehensive craft tool that would be universal with manufacturers' existing products, cut, emboss, be portable and be sturdy enough to withstand the test of time. As a result of Stacey's entrepreneurial spirit and her husband Jeff's creative ingenuity, the Wizard Universal Craft Tool was born, along with Spellbinders patented technology Die Templates for cutting, embossing and stenciling. Innovations continue with the Grand Calibur machine and the Presto Punch machine, the first automatic punching and embossing system. Start with the basic with this set of Matting Basics to create all kinds of layering in your 5 x 7 inch cards, pages and more. Create perfectly spaced layers and fancy designs with coordinating sets in the CARD Creator collection. Expand your basics by using S6-002 5 x 7 Matting Basics B set for a narrow matting option. Spellbinders Nest abilities Card Creator brings a simple and unique solution to multiple crafting projects. The work is all done for you, no more measuring required. Simply...Choose your design, Assemble your pieces, Refine the details and you're Done. Sized in 1/8 and 1/4 inch increments, choose the size from Nest abilities Card Creator set A or B for perfectly spaced layers. Approximate die template sizes are: 1-7/8 x 3-7/8 inches, 2-3/8 x 4-3/8 inches, 2-7/8 x 4-7/8 inches, 3-3/8 x 5-3/8 inches, 3-7/8 x 5-7/8 inches, 4-3/8 x 6-3/8 inches 4-7/8 x 6-7/8 inches."]
