The directions on how to use these dies with the Spellbinders Wizard, the Big Kick by Sizzix, and the Cuttlebug by Provocraft come with every set of dies, and they are very clear and easy to follow. However, the two large crosses did not cut cleanly when I applied them to Bazzill cardstock. I had to finish cutting out the center decorations with my trusty X-Acto knife, using a #11 blade. If you experience similiar problems, try rotating the die and paper 90 degrees and running it through your die-cutting machine a second time. When this didn't completely cut through the paper, I added a second sheet of paper, then flipped the first sheet of paper and die over, so that the two sheets of paper touched each other, then ran it through my Cuttlebug a third time. This technique gave me the cleanest cut, but I still had to finish the most complicated cross (the large green cross in the illustration) with my X-Acto knife. These crosses make very nice decorations for Easter greeting cards (see customer image above for an example using the large curly cross.) Title: Adds just a touch of rainbow-colored glitter to your project Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit the local library, and I go through a lot of glitter in the course of a year. This product is advertised as acid-free and non-toxic. Diamond is a great all-around color to use many different types of greeting cards to add just a touch of glitter to an object. The glue itself is transparent, so all you see is a spattering of rainbow-colored glitter, once the glue dries. See customer image for a Sympathy card where I decorated the butterfly with Diamond Stickles glitter glue.

**Product Price:** $15.59

**Product Description:** ['PAZZLES-Cutting Mats can be used with your Creative Cutter (sold separately). Treated with care these mats will last through many projects. Each package includes two cutting mats. Size: 12" x 12". Made in China.']

**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**
- Brand: Pazzles
- Main Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Cutting Mats, Quilting, Sewing
- Price Range: $10-$25

**User Review Content:**
Title: Use a lint roller to clean your cutting mat! Review: I've used both a Cricut cutter and the Pazzles Inspiration Electronic Cutter, and the Pazzles Inspiration wins, hands down. You don't have to buy expensive cartridges with the Inspiration, and the software is far superior. The only drawback I've discovered so far is that the Inspiration cutting mats are slightly more expensive. I think the extra few dollars are worth paying--however, I'm tempted to purchase a Cricut mat just to see if it works in the Inspiration. Essentially they're both 12"x12" mats, coated with a sticky surface film. When I first got my Inspiration, I set the cutting blade too deep for card stock and ended up scarring the mat, but I was still able to use it. The Inspiration users' manual suggests using a lint roller to clean the mat, and this really works! When new, the mat is very, very sticky so you really have to know how to clean it, and also how to pry delicate cuttings away from the surface. I use an X-acto knife for the latter operation.

Title: A little powder goes a long way Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit the local library, and I like to experiment with different products to use as background color. I discovered that I didn't need to apply much powder when working with Brusho Crystals to get very intense colors. All I needed to do was poke a small hole (using a corsage pin) in the lid of each jar and sprinkle a very small amount on my watercolor paper. When I spritzed water on the crystals, it was amazing to see how much color spread across the paper. Please see customer image for an A9 (5.5" x 8.5") greeting card where I created the background using blue, violet and green Brusho crystals.

**Product Title:** Tsukineko 5-Color Kaleidacolor Dye Inkpad, Baby Powder

**Product Price:** $21.25

**Product Description:** ['Kaleidacolor is Tsukineko\'s multicolor ("rainbow") dye inkpad for paper crafting of all kinds. The patented sliding pads, unique in the paper crafting industry, provide a continuous inking surface when in use. For storage, the pads slide apart to allow colors to stay fresh and true by preventing color migration. Unparalleled versatility awaits with this vibrantly color coordinated, unique, 5-color dye inkpad. Push the pads together for multi-color stamping with Tsukineko\'s Ink Sweeper (to pick up 3 bands of continuous color) or with a brayer for 5 bands of continuous color. Perfect for use with VersaMark Inkpads on glossy or coated papers to create resist effects. Separate the pads for 5 separate small inkpads in coordinating colors to use with small stamps and for easy stenciling. Also, swipe an acrylic block over the pads, and you now have 5 bands of ink color on the acrylic block that can be used as a water color palette. Available in 20 color coordinated varieties. Inkers are available for all colors. Also, un-inked Kaleidacolor pads are available to create your very own color palette.']

**Product Features:**
- Kaleidacolor is Tsukineko's multicolor ("rainbow") dye inkpad for paper crafting of all kinds; the patented sliding pads, unique in the paper crafting industry, provide a continuous inking surface when in use
- With pads touching, Kaleidacolor is excellent for multi-color stamping, creating color backgrounds, and resist techniques
- For storage, the pads slide apart to allow colors to stay fresh and true by preventing color migration; while pads are apart, 5 separate inkpads await for color coordinated watercolor palates and small stamp projects
- Water-based, cleans up easily with stazon all-purpose stamp cleaner
- Measures 5.247 by 2.742 by 0.7-inch


**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**
- Brand: Tsukineko
- Main Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Ink Pads, Scrapbooking & Stamping, Stamps & Ink Pads
- Price Range: $10-$25

**User Review Content:**
Title: Needs a bit more engineering Review: I generally make and sell between 150 - 200 greeting cards per year to benefit our local library, and I like to color some backgrounds with multi-color ink pads. Kaleidacolor is Tsukineko's multicolor ("rainbow") dye inkpad that is supposed to provide a continuous inking surface when in use, after the pads are pushed together. There is a button that makes it easy to slide the pads up next to each other. The bad news is that the button sticks up above the individual ink pads, so you can't really get at the colors nearest the button, unless you arrange to use the pad at the very edge of your work table, so that the button protrudes into space when you stamp down. Even when I used this technique, the pushed-together colors did not stamp evenly. The yellow was especially hard to stamp (see customer image). However, when I used the 'smear' technique, I did get a nice, random array of colors to decorate the Easter egg in the customer image of an A2 (5.5" x 4.25") Easter card. I like the idea of the push-together pads. It just needs a bit more engineering to make it really work.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Can be used with Cuttlebug embossing machine Review: With these butterfly dies you can perform the following functions: step (1) cut butterflies from decorative paper; step (2) emboss butterflies; step (3) color butterflies. I was able to cut and emboss these pretty butterflies with my Cuttlebug V2 Embossing & Die Cutting Machine plus Spellbinders W-023 Enlarged Embossing Pads for Wizard Cutting and Embossing System. Although the Spellbinders die cuts work without any extra parts in the Cuttlebug machine to perform step (1), you will need one of the Spellbinders embossing pads, in order to perform step (2), which is to emboss your cut-out butterflies. To perform step (3) I left the cut and embossed butterflies in the Shapeabilities dies, so that I could color the embossed (raised) parts of each butterfly. I used Clearsnap Smooch Pearlized Accent Ink Gold Lame By The Each and SMOOCH ACCNTINK GREENAPPLE.3oz Drafting, Engineering, Art (General Catalog) to color the butterflies in the above (Customer Image 1) Sympathy greeting card. Note: the directions that come with the Shapeabilities dies are easy to use, except they fail to mention that if you are using paper that has a decorative print on only one side, be sure to place the printed side of the paper against the cutting side of the die. The directions included with this product explain how to use these dies with the following machines: Big Kick by Sizzix; Original Sizzix Press; CuttleBug by Provocraft (this is the die-cutter/embosser that I use); and the Big Shot machines by Ellison-Sizzix. This is a very nice product, and easy to clean after step (3). I used Cottonelle Fresh Folded Moist Wipes Refill 84 to clean my dies.

Title: Two-piece die makes a nice anniversary card Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and this two-piece die cut set can be used for Anniversary or Friendship cards. I've been using it with my Spellbinder Grand Calibur machine. I used my Cottage Cutz metal shim to get a clean cut. Cleaning this die of all the little bits of paper can be a bit of a chore. I don't understand why Spellbinders doesn't put a cutting edge around the outside of the main die. Instead, you get a separate, rectangular die in this two-piece set. This frame die cuts a background rectangle that just fits onto an A2 (5.5" x 4.25") greeting card. Please see customer image for an A2 anniversary card that I made with the main die. Please be aware that if you use more than one color of paper in the background (I used four: blue, dark yellow, copper foil, and green glitter), you're going to be doing some fiddly cutting. I also used a gold leafing pen to color 'my sunshine' on the face of the card.

Title: I couldn't get this stencil to lie flat Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and I got this stencil to use while embossing cardstock with Metallic Copper Embossing Paste. This stencil is made from 7 mil Mylar and is quite tough. I was able to clean the paste from it, even after the paste had dried. My big problem with the stencil is that I couldn't get it to lie completely flat, even though I completely taped down the outer edge. Since I couldn't get the stencil to lie flat, some of the paste sneaked under the stencil (I was applying the paste with a Heritage Handicrafts mini-squeegee) and messed up the design. According to the advertising that comes with this stencil, you can use it in conjunction with chalk and ink or paint spritzers, but even with these products you'll need to get the stencil to lie flat.

**Product Unstructured Information:**
**Product Title:** Metallic Copper Embossing Paste

**Product Price:** $13.95

**Product Description:** ["Add some texture to your designs! This ultra-thick medium is perfect for adding texture to your creations. We love to use it with templates and stencils for raised textures in card making, on scrapbook pages, boxes, art journals and mixed media projects. Simply tape your template to your project, then use the Mini Squeegee (link) to spread the paste over the template and into the openings. Remove the template and wash it immediately. Let the paste dry. Leave as is, or mist it, rub paint or ink over it--your choice. You'll love the metallic look! From Dreamweaver Stencils, the jar contains 4 fl. oz. of paste."]


**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**
- Brand: Dream Weaver
- Main Category: Amazon Home
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Crafting, Embossing, Paper & Paper Crafts
- Price Range: $10-$25

**User Review Content:**
Title: Good color but causes cardstock to warp Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and I got this Dreamweaver Metallic Copper Embossing Paste to apply to cardstock, over a stencil. I applied the paste with a Heritage Handicrafts mini-squeegee. The directions on the jar of embossing paste weren't completely clear as to when the stencil should be removed from the cardstock after the paste was applied, so the first time I used it, I let the paste dry before I lifted the plastic stencil. This was a mistake, as the stencil stuck to the cardstock and ripped up part of the dried paste when I tried to remove it. The second application went more smoothly as I lifted the stencil as soon as I finished applying the paste. I'm still not completely satisfied with this embossing paste, as it causes the cardstock to warp as it dries. It's also hard to apply it to the smaller openings in the stencil. The color does dry to a metallic copper finish, exactly as advertised. I think the next time I'll try it on watercolor paper, which will be less prone to warping than the 80 lb. cardstock. NOTE: this paste works much better on watercolor paper and with brass stencils, rather than the plastic variety. Please see customer image for an embossed greeting card decorated with Dreamweaver Metallic Copper Embossing Paste.

**Product Title:** Cuttlebug A2 Cut and Emboss Set, Friends Forever

**Product Price:** $24.99

**Product Description:** ['Celebrate the beauty of friendship with the Friends Forever A2 Cut & Emboss Set! The coordinating embossing folder and die are perfect for cards and scrapbook layouts!']

**Product Features:**
- Die cut and embossing folder for accenting cards and other paper crafts
- Cheerful friendship-themed thoughts and greetings in a variety of fonts
- Whimsical set includes 1 A2 die cut and 1 A2 embossing folder
- Can be used in most die cutting systems

**Known Product Attributes (from Knowledge Base):**
- Brand: Cuttlebug
- Main Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing
- Category: Arts, Crafts & Sewing, Die-Cuts, Die-Cutting & Embossing, Scrapbooking & Stamping
- Price Range: $10-$25

**User Review Content:**
Title: Folder and Cutting Die--nice set Review: I like this combination of folder (the candles) and cutting die (messages plus a candle and a couple of stars) for birthday cards (see customer image above for an example using the text 'Make a Wish'). The folder works well on regular card stock, but for something special try it on mirror stock (shiny on one side, white on the other). The messages are quite useful, although the 'Sorry I Missed it' is a bit small and hard to read. I also wish Cuttlebug had spelled out 'Happy Birthday' instead of settling for 'Happy BDay.' Sizzix has a 'Happy Birthday' die that works with the Cuttlebug machine: Sizzix Sizzlits Singles Die-Medium Phrase Happy Birthday #3 although you have to be careful to apply enough pressure to cut out all of the curly bits on the letters.

Title: Good size for 'framing' on A2 greeting cards Review: Each of the oval metal dies in this collection has a piece of plastic stretched across its interior. At first, I wondered what the plastic was for, but it does make it easier to stack two ovals together and run them through the die machine together (I use the Sizzix Big Shot) in order to create frames (see customer image for a greeting card that uses a frame). You can also use the individual dies to cut solid ovals or oval windows in the body of your card.

Title: Lots of splitting, knotting, and breakage Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and I like to add embroidered edges to many of my cards, using embroidery floss or baker's twine (also called 'fancy floss'). I've used other DMC colors, and struggled a bit with them, but this dark gold color was especially challenging. The individual strands kept splitting, knotting, and breaking while I was attempting to embroider the card in the customer image. It took me nearly an hour to complete what should have been a simple task. The color is very pretty--a glimmering dark gold, but I can't recommend this floss. It's too difficult to manipulate. See customer image for a baby card I decorated with this dark gold floss.

**Product Description:** ['Pop goes the die-cut. When a Pop n Cuts base die is combined with a magnetic insert die, you can create impressive 3-D pop-up shapes in just a few quick steps. Simply pop the insert into place, lining up the center crease marks and die-cut for an incredibly easy shape-cutting experience. Measuring 6" x 13 3/4", this Pop n Cuts XL die set showcases the eye-popping style of artist Karen Burniston. The set includes the Pop n Cuts XL Horizontal A2 Card base die and Pop n Cuts Circle Label, 3-D (Pop-Up) magnetic die, but the Card base die can accommodate any of the other Pop n Cuts magnetic insert dies. The Base die can also be used without an insert to cut a card cover. The set is compatible with the BIG kick, Big Shot and Vagabond machines (with one Extended Cutting Pad, one Extended Crease Pad and 6" x 12" paper). All items sold separately. The folded Card measures approximately 4 1/4" x 5 1/2" and fits inside an A2 Envelope.']

**User Review Content:**
Title: Requires other accessories before you can use it Review: My husband got me this Pop 'n Cuts Insert for Christmas, along with the two extended clear plates that are needed to use this insert. The extended plates are not included with this product. You will have to buy them separately (they are sold at the Sizzix web site). He also got me the Sizzix Premium Extended Crease Pad, which is NOT needed (in spite of some of the advertising on youtube) to make pop-up cards. The sample card with the hollowed-out heart that is shown in the above product photograph needs yet another bit of equipment: the Sizzix Movers & Shapers Magnetic Die Set 2PK - Hearts Set. If you have a small heart die from Spellbinders, you can create the hollow heart pop-up in two steps: (1) run your card stock through your Sizzix machine to create your circular pop-up, using the Pop 'n Cuts Insert, then (2) run your cardstock back through your Sizzix machine with your Spellbinder's heart die centered on the circle. This will give you a hollowed-out heart which is very similiar to the one shown in the product photograph. I've been making pop-up valentines ever since I got my Sizzix Pop 'n Cuts die set. They're really cute, just a bit complicated to make. Luckily, there are lots of helpful videos out on Youtube that demonstrate how to make pop-up cards with this product.

Title: My favorite Stickles glitter glue Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit the local library, and I go through a lot of glitter in the course of a year. See customer image for a birthday card where I decorated the fairy's wings with Diamond Stickles glitter glue.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Takes a bit of work but makes a lovely card Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and this two-piece die cut set can be used for many different types of cards. I've been using it with my Sizzix Big Shot, and according to the 'Special Tips' sheet that comes with the Cascading Hearts die set, you should: -use an extra piece of paper as a shim (I used my CottageCutz Universal Shim Plate Die Cuts) -use a piece of wax paper between the die and cardstock -run your 'sandwich' through the machine one or two additional times to get a full cut I performed all of these steps and got a clean cut using 80 lb card stock. You'll need plenty of patience when cleaning this die of all the little leftover hearts. I don't understand why Spellbinders doesn't put a cutting edge around the outside of the Cascading Hearts die. You will have to cut the outside edge by hand. The frame die cuts a background rectangle that just fits onto an A2 (5.5" x 4.25") greeting card. Please see customer image of a baby card that I made with these two dies.

**User Review Content:**
Title: You'll need wax paper and plenty of patience to use this die. Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and this two-piece die cut set can be used to decorate many different types of cards. I've been running it through my Sizzix Big Shot, and in order to get a clean cut, I needed to use a sheet of wax paper between the die and the card stock, and run it through my die-cutting machine more than once. I tried using my CottageCutz Universal Shim Plate Die Cuts to get a cleaner cut, but it was a really tight squeeze with this die plus the wax paper. You'll need plenty of patience to work your die cut loose from the die, even with wax paper. Cleaning this die of all the little bits of paper is also a chore. I don't understand why Spellbinders doesn't put a cutting edge around the outside of the owl die. You will have to cut the outside edge by hand. The frame die cuts a background rectangle that just fits onto an A2 (5.5" x 4.25") greeting card. Please see customer image for an A2 birthday card that I made with these two dies.

Title: Pretty dies but should have more cutting edges Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local library, and I thought this four-die boutique stacker A2 frame set would make great wedding and birthday cards. I have also used them for sympathy cards. Please see customer image for an A2 (5.5" x 4.25") birthday card where I employed three of the four dies. I do have a problem with the way these dies are made: the straight (non-decorated) edges of these dies are NOT cutting edges. The smallest die has no cutting edges at all, except for those that cut out the small fleur de lis patterns. Why are they made like this? I always have to go in with my #11 X-acto blade and cut my own straight edges. I had to use a metal shim when make the initial die cut with my Spellbinders Grand Calibur machine. I've discovered that the best way to clean dies with lots of little pieces of paper that stick to the metal is to soak the die in warm water for a couple of minutes, then dig out the excess paper with a stiff-bristled brush, using small circular motions.

Title: A good ink pad for embossed paper Review: I generally make and sell between 150 - 200 greeting cards per year, and I like to emboss the backgrounds, and then color them so that the raised pattern stands out. It's advertised as creating "an aged look on papers, fibers, photos & more" which wasn't quite what I was looking for. But it also works very well for coloring a raised pattern after I've run my cardstock through my Cuttlebug with an embossing folder. Please see the customer image for a sympathy card that I embossed with an autumn-themed folder, then colored with the vintage photo Distress Ink pad. The only drawback to using this Distress Ink pad is that it takes a few minutes to dry. The vintage photo color will appear to be dark brown on almost any color of card stock.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Finally, a decent applicator for quilling and card-making Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local libraries, and one of my least favorite tasks is gluing bits of paper together, especially if I have to glue an intricate cut-out (Scherenschnitte) or a quilled flower. This precision-tip applicator bottle is the closest I've ever found to the perfect gluing bottle. If you are careful how you squeeze the plastic bottle, you can apply fine dots or lines of glue to your paper. Furthermore, the glue doesn't seem to stay in the tip and clog it up like it does in my all-plastic applicator bottles. Sometimes the attached tip gets in my way when I'm gluing a particularly detailed die-cut, e.g. text, but that's a minor inconvenience.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Cuts very well but an odd size Review: Die-Namites dies are made here in the USA from 100% steel and work with all major die-cutting tools in the market. They are relatively small, thin, quite intricate and cut very well on my Spellbinders Grand Calibur machine. This particular die makes quite an elegant corner for a variety of different cards, including wedding, friendship, and birthday (see customer image for a wedding card I made from four die-cuts from this die). My only problem with 'Scrolly Corner' is that if you cut four pieces for a frame, the only card it will fit is a 6" square card. Here in the USA, we have to pay extra postage for square cards, so I don't usually make them. I was able to remove bits from the die-cuts and get them to fit on a 5.5" square card, for which I had a standard square envelope. Note to the Manufacturer: Dear Die-Namites, if you want to sell lots of corner dies, please make ones that will fit on a standard A2 (5.5" x 4.25") greeting card.

Title: The 'burlap' folder leaves a lizard-skin impression Review: I make and sell greeting cards to benefit our local libraries and these two embossing folders add a nice dimension to the background of my A2 (5.5" x 4.25") card faces. They are both non-thematic, so can be used with any type of card. The 'burlap' folder embosses a pattern that looks like lizard hide. I create the raised pattern on cardstock by running the cardstock and embossing folder through my Cuttlebug machine. I either leave the raised pattern uncolored or else use a cosmetic sponge and an ink pad to dab color on the raised portion. Chalk could also be used, but you would probably want to use a sealant to keep the chalk from migrating off of the card surface.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Cute die cut but a bit of a gluing challenge Review: This die-cut set yields a cute present that measures about 1.5" x 1.75" when all of the pieces are glued together. I use the assembled die cut both inside and on the outside of my birthday and Christmas cards. You can face your present with polka-dots, hearts, or stripes, depending on which die you use. You will be gluing four pieces of paper together, and I often add glitter to the bow. The only problem with assembling the four pieces of paper is that there is no really good way to glue the package top onto the package body. I tried gluing the bow to the package top, and then gluing the bottom of the bow onto the package body, but had trouble lining up the top with the body. What seemed to work better for me was to glue an extra piece of paper behind the package body, with a little strip sticking up over the top. Then I glued the package top to that exposed strip of paper. That gave me a nice, tight fit.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Perfect for creating Valentine cards Review: If you like the layered look on your greeting cards (see above customer image of a heart-shaped greeting card using this die set) or scrapbook pages, these Spellbinders nestabilities dies are the perfect accessory for your embossing/die-cutting machine. I use them with my Spellbinders Grand Calibur Embossing & Die Cutting Machine, and according to the directions that come with the dies, they also work with the Cuttlebugs and the Sizzix machines. The directions that come with these dies explain very clearly how to use them with each type of embossing/die-cutting machine. NOTE: if you are accumulating quite a collection of these Spellbinders dies, you might find it handy to create a binder to hold them. I bought a three-inch binder and about 28 feet of 1/2" magnetic tape, and made pages out of cardboard and chipboard. I stuck the magnetic tape onto both sides of a cardboard page, usually in a cross-shape, then stuck the dies to the magnetic tape. The dies are much easier to remove and put back onto the magnetic tape than they were to take off and put back onto onto the sticky tape that Spellbinders uses to package them. Plus all my dies are in one place now, and very easy to access. See second customer image above for a sample page from my 'metal dies' binder.

**User Review Content:**
Title: Lovely colors, but they never completely set Review: I wouldn't call this ink pad a toy. It's more of a hobby item for papercrafters. I use it in conjunction with a rubber stamp to decorate greeting cards (see image above). The four colors of ink--green, blue, rose, and mauve--go quite well together, and the resulting image is imbued with a metallic sheen. I've been stamping hearts and swans on Valentine cards with this 'enchanted evening' pad. The hues are soft, rather than saturated with color. My only problem with the inks in this pad is that they do not set completely, and will smear even after 24-hours (this was on Aquarelle Arches hot-pressed watercolor paper, 140 lb. weight). You might want to spray your finished image with a fixative such as Krylon Workable Fixatif Spray- 11 oz..

**Product Title:** Spellbinders S5-135 Nestabilities Card Creator A2 Fancy Ribbon Threader Die Templates

**Product Price:** $19.11

**Product Description:** ["As a scrapbooking and craft enthusiast, Stacey Caron identified the market need for one die cutting system that could function in place of several existing tools. She wanted a comprehensive craft tool that would be universal with manufacturers' existing products, cut, emboss, be portable and be sturdy enough to withstand the test of time. Innovations continue with the Grand Calibur machine and the Presto Punch machine, the first automatic punching and embossing system. Spellbinders Paper Arts entered the craft and hobby market in 2003 and now has more than 250 patented and patent pending products under the trade names of Nestabilities, Edgeabilities, Shapeabilities, Borderabilities and Nesties. Layering, patterns and detail seem to be the buzz words on everyone's lips this year, so we've made sure to create a fabulous assortment of new die designs that give you all three and bring you wonderful options for creativity. Spellbinders Nestabilities Card Creator, in collaboration with Cindy Echtinaw, brings a simple and unique solution to multiple crafting projects. The work's all done for you, no more measuring required. Based on the ever popular Nestabilities line, the new Card Creator die templates are sized to work with standard A2 size cards. The collection includes 2 basic matting sets, sizes A and B. When using Size A or B within their respective sets, incrementing will be achieved at 1/4-inch. When combining A and B, 1/8-inch incrementing is achieved. The other four sets offer decorative designs that are perfectly proportioned for an A2 card. Simply choose your design, assemble your pieces, refine the details and you're done. A unique set that is a must have for anyone who loves to add ribbon to their cards and projects. The fancy edges and details are added bonus in this four piece set. Approximate die template sizes are: Label; 1-5/8 by 5/8-inch, Accent; 2-3/4 by 7/8-inch, Small rectangle; 1-7/8 by 3-1/8-inch and Large rectangle; 3-7/8 by 5-1/8-inch."]

**Product Features:**
- The Nestabilities Card Creator brings a simple and unique solution to multiple crafting projects
- The fancy edges and details add a unique look to cards and paper projects
- Cindy Echtinaw brings fancy and easy to use design to creative projects

**User Review Content:**
Title: Useful Dies for all sorts of greeting cards Review: The Spellbinders A-2 Fancy Ribbon die set is useful for all sorts of greeting cards. This particular set consists of four dies: the largest is just the right size for an A2 (5.5" x 4.25") greeting card. I used it to cut 80 lb. card stock. It takes awhile to clean the dies after they've been used, but the two larger dies are designed so that you can thread ribbon through the slots and twine through the smaller holes. Please see customer image for an example of a baby card that was made with the largest die. I threaded twine around the outer edge, and ribbon through the slots at the bottom of the die-cut.
